McCain, Sr.]] aboard [[USS Shangri-La (CV-38)]]]] '''John Lawrence Sullivan''' (June 16, 1899 â€“ August 8, 1982) was [[Assistant Secretary of the Navy (AIR)]] 1946-47 and the first [[United States Department of Defense|Department of Defense]] [[United States Secretary of the Navy|Secretary of the Navy]] in the [[Harry S. Truman|Truman]] Administration 1947-49. He was appointed to that position upon [[James V. Forrestal|Secretary Forrestal]]'s installation as the first [[Secretary of Defense]]. He resigned in protest after the second Secretary of Defense, [[Louis A. Johnson]], canceled the heavy aircraft carrier [[USS United States (CVA-58)|''United States'']]. This event was part of an [[Interservice rivalry|interservice conflict]] known as the [[Revolt of the Admirals]]. Sullivan's major contributions to the Navy's future directions include the advent of naval nuclear propulsion. In 1947, then-Captain [[Hyman G. Rickover]] [[Hyman_G._Rickover#Naval reactors and the Atomic Energy Commission|went around his chain-of-command]] and directly to the Chief of Naval Operations, [[Chester W. Nimitz|Fleet Admiral Chester Nimitz]], by chance also a former submariner, to pitch his ideas for creating a nuclear-powered warship. Nimitz immediately understood the potential of nuclear propulsion and recommended the project to Sullivan, whose endorsement to build the world's first nuclear-powered vessel, [[USS Nautilus (SSN-571)|USS ''Nautilus'' (SSN-571)]], later caused Rickover to state that Sullivan was "the true father of the Nuclear Navy."<ref>http://books.google.com/books?id=rVMEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA104&dq=Rickover&hl=en&sa=X&ei=hcbsTpK3GeqtsAL8243CCQ&ved=0CGAQ6AEwCQ#v=onepage&q=Rickover&f=false LIFE magazine, September 8, 1958, page 108</ref><ref>http://www.seacoastonline.com/articles/20111216-ENTERTAIN-112160303</ref> ==Biography== Born in [[Manchester, New Hampshire]], he was an alumnus of [[Dartmouth College]].<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.trumanlibrary.org/hstpaper/sullivan.htm | title = John L. Sullivan Papers | publisher = Truman Library | accessdate = 2007-08-20 }}</ref> He died on August 8, 1982. A biographical book entitled ''A Different Time, A Different Man'' written by Stephen Clarkson chronicles the life of Sullivan.<ref>http://www.seacoastonline.com/articles/20111216-ENTERTAIN-112160303</ref> ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{commons category}} *[http://www.arlingtoncemetery.net/jlsulliv.htm Arlington National Cemetery] *[http://www.trumanlibrary.org/hstpaper/sullivan.htm Sullivan's Papers at the Harry S.
